sets.setTitle: Set 1: Also, As Well As, Apart From

examples.before: She speaks French. She <<also>> speaks Spanish.
examples.after: She speaks French. She <<also>> speaks Spanish. / She speaks French <<as well as>> Spanish.

examples.before: The hotel has a gym. <<Apart from>> that, it has a swimming pool.
examples.after: The hotel has a gym. <<Apart from>> that, it has a swimming pool.

examples.before: He is intelligent. He is <<also>> very hardworking.
examples.after: He is intelligent. He is <<also>> very hardworking. / He is intelligent <<as well as>> hardworking.

examples.before: <<Apart from>> English, she speaks three other languages.
examples.after: <<Apart from>> English, she speaks three other languages.

examples.before: The course includes grammar. It <<also>> includes vocabulary practice.
examples.after: The course includes grammar. It <<also>> includes vocabulary practice.

examples.before: I don't want to go out. <<Besides>>, it's raining.
examples.after: I don't want to go out. <<Besides>>, it's raining.

examples.before: The restaurant serves excellent food. <<Furthermore>>, the service is outstanding.
examples.after: The restaurant serves excellent food. <<Furthermore>>, the service is outstanding.

examples.before: He's a talented musician. <<Moreover>>, he's a gifted painter.
examples.after: He's a talented musician. <<Moreover>>, he's a gifted painter.

examples.before: The job offers good salary. <<Besides>>, it provides great benefits.
examples.after: The job offers good salary. <<Besides>>, it provides great benefits.

examples.before: The city has excellent museums. <<Furthermore>>, it has beautiful parks.
examples.after: The city has excellent museums. <<Furthermore>>, it has beautiful parks.

sets.setTitle: Set 3: In Addition, What Is More, Not Only...But Also

examples.before: The course is affordable. <<In addition>>, it's very comprehensive.
examples.after: The course is affordable. <<In addition>>, it's very comprehensive.

examples.before: She's highly qualified. <<What is more>>, she has years of experience.
examples.after: She's highly qualified. <<What is more>>, she has years of experience.

examples.before: He <<not only>> passed the exam <<but also>> got the highest grade.
examples.after: He <<not only>> passed the exam <<but also>> got the highest grade.

examples.before: The hotel is centrally located. <<In addition>>, it's reasonably priced.
examples.after: The hotel is centrally located. <<In addition>>, it's reasonably priced.

examples.before: They <<not only>> won the match <<but also>> broke the record.
examples.after: They <<not only>> won the match <<but also>> broke the record.

examples.before: The film was long, <<but>> it was interesting.
examples.after: The film was long, <<but>> it was interesting. / The film was long. <<However>>, it was interesting.

examples.before: She studied hard. <<However>>, she didn't pass the exam.
examples.after: She studied hard. <<However>>, she didn't pass the exam.

examples.before: The weather was terrible. <<Nevertheless>>, we enjoyed our trip.
examples.after: The weather was terrible. <<Nevertheless>>, we enjoyed our trip.

examples.before: It was expensive, <<but>> it was worth it.
examples.after: It was expensive, <<but>> it was worth it. / It was expensive. <<However>>, it was worth it.

examples.before: He's very talented. <<However>>, he lacks experience.
examples.after: He's very talented. <<However>>, he lacks experience.

examples.before: <<Although>> it was raining, we went out.
examples.after: <<Although>> it was raining, we went out. / We went out <<although>> it was raining.

examples.before: <<Though>> she's young, she's very mature.
examples.after: <<Though>> she's young, she's very mature. / She's very mature <<though>> she's young.

examples.before: <<Even though>> he was tired, he finished the work.
examples.after: <<Even though>> he was tired, he finished the work.

examples.before: <<Although>> the hotel was expensive, it was comfortable.
examples.after: <<Although>> the hotel was expensive, it was comfortable.

examples.before: <<Though>> I tried hard, I couldn't solve the problem.
examples.after: <<Though>> I tried hard, I couldn't solve the problem.

sets.setTitle: Set 3: Despite, In Spite Of, Whereas, While

examples.before: <<Despite>> the rain, we enjoyed the picnic.
examples.after: <<Despite>> the rain, we enjoyed the picnic. / <<In spite of>> the rain, we enjoyed the picnic.

examples.before: He succeeded <<despite>> many difficulties.
examples.after: He succeeded <<despite>> many difficulties. / He succeeded <<in spite of>> many difficulties.

examples.before: She loves summer, <<whereas>> I prefer winter.
examples.after: She loves summer, <<whereas>> I prefer winter.

examples.before: Tom is outgoing, <<while>> his brother is shy.
examples.after: Tom is outgoing, <<while>> his brother is shy.

examples.before: <<Despite>> being tired, she continued working.
examples.after: <<Despite>> being tired, she continued working.

examples.before: I stayed home <<because>> I was ill.
examples.after: I stayed home <<because>> I was ill. / <<Because>> I was ill, I stayed home.

examples.before: <<Since>> it was late, we decided to leave.
examples.after: <<Since>> it was late, we decided to leave. / We decided to leave <<since>> it was late.

examples.before: <<As>> she was tired, she went to bed early.
examples.after: <<As>> she was tired, she went to bed early.

examples.before: They cancelled the match <<because>> of the weather.
examples.after: They cancelled the match <<because>> of the weather.

examples.before: <<Since>> you're here, can you help me?
examples.after: <<Since>> you're here, can you help me?

sets.setTitle: Set 2: Due To, Owing To, Because Of

examples.before: The flight was delayed <<due to>> bad weather.
examples.after: The flight was delayed <<due to>> bad weather.

examples.before: <<Owing to>> illness, she couldn't attend the meeting.
examples.after: <<Owing to>> illness, she couldn't attend the meeting.

examples.before: The match was postponed <<because of>> the rain.
examples.after: The match was postponed <<because of>> the rain.

examples.before: <<Due to>> heavy traffic, we arrived late.
examples.after: <<Due to>> heavy traffic, we arrived late.

examples.before: The project failed <<owing to>> lack of funding.
examples.after: The project failed <<owing to>> lack of funding.

sets.setTitle: Set 3: On Account Of, For This Reason, That's Why

examples.before: The event was cancelled <<on account of>> the storm.
examples.after: The event was cancelled <<on account of>> the storm.

examples.before: He was exhausted. <<For this reason>>, he went straight to bed.
examples.after: He was exhausted. <<For this reason>>, he went straight to bed.

examples.before: She studied hard. <<That's why>> she passed the exam.
examples.after: She studied hard. <<That's why>> she passed the exam.

examples.before: Schools were closed <<on account of>> the snow.
examples.after: Schools were closed <<on account of>> the snow.

examples.before: The restaurant was full. <<For this reason>>, we went somewhere else.
examples.after: The restaurant was full. <<For this reason>>, we went somewhere else.

examples.before: It was raining, <<so>> we stayed home.
examples.after: It was raining, <<so>> we stayed home.

examples.before: The shop was closed. <<Therefore>>, we couldn't buy anything.
examples.after: The shop was closed. <<Therefore>>, we couldn't buy anything.

examples.before: He missed the bus. <<Consequently>>, he was late for work.
examples.after: He missed the bus. <<Consequently>>, he was late for work.

examples.before: She was tired, <<so>> she went to bed early.
examples.after: She was tired, <<so>> she went to bed early.

examples.before: The restaurant was full. <<Therefore>>, we had to wait.
examples.after: The restaurant was full. <<Therefore>>, we had to wait.

sets.setTitle: Set 2: As A Result, Thus, Hence

examples.before: It snowed heavily. <<As a result>>, all flights were cancelled.
examples.after: It snowed heavily. <<As a result>>, all flights were cancelled.

examples.before: He studied every day. <<Thus>>, he passed with excellent grades.
examples.after: He studied every day. <<Thus>>, he passed with excellent grades.

examples.before: The evidence was clear. <<Hence>>, he was found guilty.
examples.after: The evidence was clear. <<Hence>>, he was found guilty.

examples.before: She trained hard. <<As a result>>, she won the competition.
examples.after: She trained hard. <<As a result>>, she won the competition.

examples.before: The company made losses. <<Thus>>, they had to cut jobs.
examples.after: The company made losses. <<Thus>>, they had to cut jobs.

sets.setTitle: Set 3: As A Consequence, For This Reason

examples.before: He broke the rules. <<As a consequence>>, he was expelled.
examples.after: He broke the rules. <<As a consequence>>, he was expelled.

examples.before: The weather was terrible. <<For this reason>>, the event was cancelled.
examples.after: The weather was terrible. <<For this reason>>, the event was cancelled.

examples.before: Sales dropped significantly. <<As a consequence>>, the store closed.
examples.after: Sales dropped significantly. <<As a consequence>>, the store closed.

examples.before: She had no experience. <<For this reason>>, she didn't get the job.
examples.after: She had no experience. <<For this reason>>, she didn't get the job.

examples.before: Traffic was heavy. <<As a consequence>>, we missed our flight.
examples.after: Traffic was heavy. <<As a consequence>>, we missed our flight.

title: PURPOSE
subtitle: To, In order to, So that

sets.setTitle: Set 1: To, In Order To, So As To

examples.before: She went to the library <<to>> study.
examples.after: She went to the library <<to>> study. / She went to the library <<in order to>> study.

examples.before: He's saving money <<in order to>> buy a car.
examples.after: He's saving money <<in order to>> buy a car. / He's saving money <<to>> buy a car.

examples.before: They left early <<so as to>> avoid traffic.
examples.after: They left early <<so as to>> avoid traffic.

examples.before: I'm learning English <<to>> get a better job.
examples.after: I'm learning English <<to>> get a better job.

examples.before: She set an alarm <<in order to>> wake up early.
examples.after: She set an alarm <<in order to>> wake up early.

sets.setTitle: Set 2: So That, In Order That

examples.before: I'll write it down <<so that>> I don't forget.
examples.after: I'll write it down <<so that>> I don't forget.

examples.before: She spoke slowly <<so that>> everyone could understand.
examples.after: She spoke slowly <<so that>> everyone could understand.

examples.before: He saved money <<in order that>> he could buy a house.
examples.after: He saved money <<in order that>> he could buy a house.

examples.before: They arrived early <<so that>> they could get good seats.
examples.after: They arrived early <<so that>> they could get good seats.

examples.before: I'm studying hard <<so that>> I can pass the exam.
examples.after: I'm studying hard <<so that>> I can pass the exam.

sets.setTitle: Set 3: For The Purpose Of, With The Aim Of

examples.before: The meeting was arranged <<for the purpose of>> discussing the budget.
examples.after: The meeting was arranged <<for the purpose of>> discussing the budget.

examples.before: They launched the campaign <<with the aim of>> raising awareness.
examples.after: They launched the campaign <<with the aim of>> raising awareness.

examples.before: She joined the course <<for the purpose of>> improving her skills.
examples.after: She joined the course <<for the purpose of>> improving her skills.

examples.before: The program was created <<with the aim of>> helping students.
examples.after: The program was created <<with the aim of>> helping students.

examples.before: He traveled to Spain <<for the purpose of>> learning Spanish.
examples.after: He traveled to Spain <<for the purpose of>> learning Spanish.

examples.before: She's intelligent. <<Furthermore>>, she's very creative.
examples.after: She's intelligent. <<Furthermore>>, she's very creative.

examples.before: <<Although>> it was expensive, we bought it.
examples.after: <<Although>> it was expensive, we bought it.

examples.before: He speaks French. He <<also>> speaks German.
examples.after: He speaks French. He <<also>> speaks German.

examples.before: The hotel was clean. <<However>>, it was noisy.
examples.after: The hotel was clean. <<However>>, it was noisy.

examples.before: <<Despite>> the rain, we enjoyed the trip.
examples.after: <<Despite>> the rain, we enjoyed the trip.

examples.before: It was late, <<so>> we went home.
examples.after: It was late, <<so>> we went home.

examples.before: The match was cancelled <<due to>> bad weather.
examples.after: The match was cancelled <<due to>> bad weather.

examples.before: He was ill. <<Therefore>>, he stayed home.
examples.after: He was ill. <<Therefore>>, he stayed home.

examples.before: <<Because>> she studied hard, she passed the exam.
examples.after: <<Because>> she studied hard, she passed the exam.

examples.before: The roads were icy. <<Consequently>>, many accidents occurred.
examples.after: The roads were icy. <<Consequently>>, many accidents occurred.

examples.before: She went to the library <<in order to>> study.
examples.after: She went to the library <<in order to>> study.

examples.before: <<In addition>>, the course includes practical work.
examples.after: <<In addition>>, the course includes practical work.

examples.before: He trained every day. <<As a result>>, he won the race.
examples.after: He trained every day. <<As a result>>, he won the race.

examples.before: <<Though>> it was difficult, she didn't give up.
examples.after: <<Though>> it was difficult, she didn't give up.

examples.before: They left early <<so that>> they could avoid traffic.
examples.after: They left early <<so that>> they could avoid traffic.
